scenes.sceneDescription: You arrive at the SPINDLE site to close it, and the first thing the facility offers is a contradiction: one sign insists it is decommissioned, another insists it is operational. The fence is chained, the road is cracked, and something inside is quietly still supplying power in a way that feels less like “working” and more like “refusing to stop.”

characters.notes: Arrives at the SPINDLE site gate to begin formal closure; notes the contradictory signage as a compliance problem to log (not a mystery). Establishes tutorial tone: methodical inspection, documentation-first mindset.

possibleOutcomes.description: Tutorial context is established; the signage conflict is noted as a compliance problem, not a mystery.

scenes.sceneDescription: Your trunk provides the only part of this project that behaves like it was planned: hardhat, safety glasses, multimeter, TEMPORARY labels, a blank inspection tag, a low-battery label maker, and a clipboard titled “Closure Package – SPINDLE Site (Draft).” The binder is empty in the way a threat is empty.

characters.notes: Alone at the car trunk; collects the starter kit and the empty 'Closure Package – SPINDLE Site (Draft)' binder shell. No NPC interaction in this beat.

possibleOutcomes.description: You collect the starter kit and the binder shell.

scenes.sceneDescription: The gate keypad accepts your input with the enthusiasm of a tax form. It cannot open the gate, but it can print a receipt. The receipt is small, thin, and confident: “ACCESS ATTEMPT RECORDED. REQUEST ROUTED TO RECORDS.”

characters.notes: Interacts with the gate keypad/receipt slot; cannot open the gate but triggers the receipt print and collects it as evidence/paper trail.

possibleOutcomes.description: You obtain the access attempt receipt and gain a new problem: Records must authorize entry, and Records is not currently doing things.

scenes.sceneDescription: You read the layered signage closely. The fonts disagree, the dates disagree, and the authority lines disagree. The facility isn’t secured so much as it is litigated in advance.

characters.notes: POV character. Closely inspects the layered signpost, recognizes contradictory dates/authorities/fonts, and frames the discovery as a formal compliance conflict to be logged into the closure paperwork.

possibleOutcomes.description: You formally note the contradiction as a compliance conflict requiring resolution.

scenes.sceneDescription: The guard shack sits just inside the fence line like a small museum exhibit titled SECURITY (HISTORICAL). The door is locked. The card reader is technically on, in the way a dying watch is technically keeping time.

characters.notes: Arrives at the guard shack exterior and assesses the locked door and weakly powered card reader.

possibleOutcomes.description: You confirm the door is locked and the reader is underpowered.

scenes.sceneDescription: The call box routes you to an offsite security vendor who can’t verify you, but can verify whether you are scheduled. They explain, carefully, that “presence” is a paperwork condition. If Records marks you onsite, security can treat you as a fact.

characters.notes: Initiates the call box interaction; asks concise verification/scheduling questions and pushes for actionable next steps.

Voice-only via call box. Cannot verify identity/authorization, but can confirm whether the PLAYER is scheduled. Carefully explains that 'presence' is a paperwork/system state; advises that if Records marks the PLAYER onsite, security can treat them as present and act accordingly.

possibleOutcomes.description: You learn the path forward: get marked ‘onsite’ by Records, even if Records is a locked room.

scenes.sceneDescription: A metal plate by the door lists tube routes like they’re still in use: “RECORDS ↔ SECURITY ↔ OPERATIONS.” The tube itself is dead, but the labeling is strangely confident, as if confidence could substitute for pressure.

characters.notes: Examines the pneumatic-tube label plate and records the listed route relationship as a procedural note for later leverage.

possibleOutcomes.description: You record the tube routing relationship as a likely future lever.

effects.value: Tube routing plate: RECORDS ↔ SECURITY ↔ OPERATIONS (labeled even if dead).

scenes.sceneDescription: Inside the vestibule, security is reduced to two categories: expired supplies and old assumptions. A badge insert dispenser offers stock that hasn’t been relevant in years, which makes it perfect for a system that only recognizes artifacts.

characters.notes: POV character searching the vestibule for usable badge artifacts and sign-in materials; methodical, treats outdated supplies as system keys.

Voice-only via the speaker/intercom if contacted; follows vendor script, cannot verify identity, can only act when paperwork/artifacts indicate the player is 'scheduled' or otherwise recognized by the system.

possibleOutcomes.description: You identify usable badge materials and likely sign-in artifacts.

scenes.sceneDescription: You pull an expired visitor badge insert from the dispenser. It is visibly out of date, which is helpful: nothing here seems to accept ‘current,’ only ‘present.’

characters.notes: Physically present in the Guard Shack Vestibule; pulls an expired visitor badge insert from the wall dispenser as a procedural workaround (system accepts 'present,' not 'current').

possibleOutcomes.description: You collect the visitor badge insert as a required artifact for later sign-in steps.

scenes.sceneDescription: The desk drawer contains old badge stock, including a contractor badge that looks real enough to satisfy a machine that doesn’t know what year it is. The stripe is dead—magnetically, not spiritually.

characters.notes: Interacts with the security desk drawer and collects the demagnetized contractor badge.

possibleOutcomes.description: You collect the demagnetized contractor badge for later restoration.

scenes.sceneDescription: The ground hatch opens into a shallow utility pit. The space feels maintained by inertia: conduit runs still make sense, labels still exist, and the door inward still waits like it expects to be used by someone who is properly logged.

characters.notes: Physically present at the exterior ground service hatch; climbs down into the shallow utility pit and assesses the maintained conduit runs, labels, and the inward service door as the next access point.

possibleOutcomes.description: You reach the service access point used to wake minimal building loads.

scenes.sceneDescription: You bring up minimal auxiliary power from the service access. Breaker labels disagree across eras, so you verify with your multimeter instead of trusting history. The label maker gets a brief charge—just enough to be helpful, not enough to be smug about it.

characters.notes: Performs the auxiliary power bring-up from the service access; verifies mismatched breaker labels with a multimeter and briefly charges the label maker.

possibleOutcomes.description: Auxiliary loads come online; you can power small systems and print limited labels.

scenes.sceneDescription: With auxiliary power restored, the card reader wakes properly and immediately asks for two things: an active badge and a training date. It prints a slip that reads like a verdict: “Training date required. Consult Records.”

characters.notes: Interacts with the re-powered card reader; attempts access, is prompted for badge and training date, and collects the printed 'Training date required. Consult Records.' slip for the closure binder.

possibleOutcomes.description: You obtain the training-date-required slip for the binder and confirm Records is now a gate, not a room.

scenes.sceneDescription: The admin lobby is 1979 trapped in laminate. The kiosk boots to a limited menu that demands an employee ID, which is a charming request given the facility’s overall commitment to being unstaffed.

characters.notes: Alone in the admin lobby, inspecting the kiosk/menu, phone list, desk drawers, and partially obscured SPINDLE asset plaque to gather identifiers and fabricate procedural authority.

possibleOutcomes.description: You identify the lobby kiosk, phone list, and the asset plaque as the main artifacts needed to fabricate authority.

scenes.sceneDescription: The wall phone list is old enough to be sentimental. Most numbers dead-end, but one still routes to OLEA Legal. The list doesn’t say that; it just implies it, like an apology.

characters.notes: Interacts with the wall phone list; identifies and records the still-valid Legal extension as a usable escalation/reference channel.

possibleOutcomes.description: You note Legal’s extension as a usable supervisor reference and escalation channel.

scenes.sceneDescription: You peel back contractor stickers from a faded plaque and recover the only identity the building still seems willing to admit: “S.P.I.N.D.L.E. NODE: SP-01 / Commissioned 1979.” It feels less like a name and more like a legal handle.

characters.notes: Interacts with the faded asset plaque; peels back contractor stickers and records the discovered asset handle (SP-01).

possibleOutcomes.description: You record the SP-01 asset ID to unlock Legal’s willingness to generate a work order.

scenes.sceneDescription: In the reception desk drawers you find the kind of miscellaneous office debris that becomes critical only when the building refuses to recognize you. A small magnetized component—speaker salvage, desk toy, something—will do the job.

characters.notes: Rummages through the reception desk drawers and discovers/collects the small magnetic component.

possibleOutcomes.description: You obtain a small magnetic component suitable for restoring a badge stripe ‘just enough.’

scenes.sceneDescription: You call OLEA Legal. They refuse to “authorize entry,” but they can issue a Work Order if you provide the asset ID. Their tone suggests the definition of ‘authorize’ is the only thing keeping them alive.

characters.notes: Initiates the call from the Admin Lobby phone list; asks for entry/authorization or a Work Order. Keeps responses concise and procedural; may or may not have the asset ID (SP-01) available.

Voice-only on the phone. Refuses to use or accept 'authorize entry' language; will issue a Work Order only if given the correct asset ID. Tone is defensive and definition-focused; adds careful disclaimers and narrow-purpose wording.

possibleOutcomes.description: Without the asset ID, Legal cannot issue a work order and the call ends with careful disclaimers.

effects.value: Legal: needs asset ID to issue Work Order. Refused ‘authorization’ language.

possibleOutcomes.description: With SP-01, Legal issues a Work Order and sends it to the facility’s posted fax number, regardless of whether the fax machine is awake enough to feel shame.

effects.value: Work Order issued by Legal for SP-01; routed to posted facility fax.

scenes.sceneDescription: Records is a door with a seal strip that implies recent certainty. The pneumatic tube station sits nearby, labeled as if it expects collaboration between departments that no longer exist in the same decade.

characters.notes: Inspects the sealed, locked Records door and nearby tube station/fire panel note to identify alternate procedural routes to authority.

possibleOutcomes.description: You confirm Records is locked and identify the fire panel and tube station as alternate routes to authority.

scenes.sceneDescription: The fire panel has a taped SOP note in handwriting that is trying not to be responsible: “KEYS IN FIRE PANEL PER SOP.” Inside is a small ring labeled “TEMPORARY,” which feels like the facility’s entire governance model.

characters.notes: Interacts with the fire panel SOP note and retrieves the key ring labeled “TEMPORARY” (if not already collected).

possibleOutcomes.description: You collect the TEMPORARY key ring, expanding your ability to open locked support spaces without anyone admitting that’s what you’re doing.

scenes.sceneDescription: The copy/fax room is a shrine to bureaucratic endurance. The copier is alive enough to complain. The fax machine is alive enough to threaten to stop. Supplies are present, but only if you can access them as a person the building recognizes.

characters.notes: Navigates the copy/fax room puzzle: copier service-code prompt, fax low-toner behavior, and supply access; identifies materials needed for the minimum closure binder.
Implied via legacy contractor sticker-over-sticker service-code label; if the player follows any service-number trail, the contractor’s scope-limiting voicemail can surface here.

possibleOutcomes.description: You identify the machinery and supplies needed to assemble the minimum closure binder.

scenes.sceneDescription: The fax machine coughs out Legal’s work order in fragmented pages, as if it’s trying to reduce its own liability by being unreadable. You re-run until the essential parts exist in triplicate, which is the closest thing to truth this building respects.

characters.notes: Interacts with the fax machine tray; re-runs the fax until essential pages are legible and duplicated for the closure binder.
Not physically present; their involvement is via the faxed Work Order. Document language should reflect definition-control, liability-minimizing phrasing and narrow-purpose clauses.

possibleOutcomes.description: You receive the Work Order pages and can begin assembling the binder.

scenes.sceneDescription: The copier demands a service code. The code sticker is covered by a newer sticker, which is covered by an older sticker pretending it’s newer. You print a “TEMPORARY LIFT” tag and peel the top layer ‘legally.’ The copier accepts the revealed code with the moral tone of a judge.

characters.notes: Physically interacts with the copier and the layered service-code sticker stack; uses the charged label maker to print a “TEMPORARY LIFT” tag to justify peeling the top sticker layer and revealing the service code.

possibleOutcomes.description: You recover the copier service code and unlock copying for binder assembly.

scenes.sceneDescription: You assemble the Minimum Closure Package binder: Work Order, Site Access Log placeholders, Training Verification section (or waiver), LOTO plan section, and an Operational Status Verification checklist tab that feels like it’s watching you. The copier prints “UNCONTROLLED WHEN PRINTED” in the footer, which is either a warning or a thesis.

characters.notes: Physically assembles the Minimum Closure Package binder at the supplies shelf; no NPC interaction required in this beat. Keep the player’s action competent and procedural, with dry internal commentary implied by the scene description.

possibleOutcomes.description: The binder reaches a functional threshold, enabling later access attempts and procedural gates.

scenes.sceneDescription: The kiosk wants a scannable badge and a supervisor reference. You restore ‘just enough’ magnetism to the contractor badge and enter a supervisor extension instead of a name. The kiosk prints a Temporary Presence Receipt with a disclaimer that tries to sound casual about being legally uncertain.

characters.notes: Uses the lobby kiosk terminal to spoof presence: restores enough magnetism to a contractor badge to scan, then enters a supervisor extension (not a name) to satisfy the kiosk and print a Temporary Presence Receipt (TPR).

possibleOutcomes.description: Without a badge artifact and a supervisor extension, the kiosk refuses to file you as present.
You fabricate valid presence: a Temporary Presence Receipt the security vendor will accept as reality ‘in the normal sense.’

scenes.sceneDescription: With your Temporary Presence Receipt on file, the offsite vendor’s tone shifts from helpless to procedural. The interior door is remotely unlocked, not because anyone trusts you, but because the system now has somewhere to put the blame if you are crushed by a door.

characters.notes: At the guard shack exterior using the call box/card reader; provides/relies on the Temporary Presence Receipt as proof-of-presence.

Voice through the call box; tone shifts from helpless to procedural once the Temporary Presence Receipt is confirmed on file; remotely unlocks the interior door without implying trust or authorization.

possibleOutcomes.description: The guard shack interior access is enabled.

scenes.sceneDescription: The conference room contains a fresh stack of paperwork that looks like it arrived after you did. The External Assurance Contractor’s presence is implied by the Finding Slip printer tray: a single sheet, already stamped, already blocking something you haven’t tried yet.

characters.notes: Enters the conference room and discovers the newly-arrived paperwork stack and the stamped Finding Slip; can pick up/trigger issuance outcome.

Not necessarily physically present; presence is conveyed through the freshly printed, pre-stamped Finding Slip and staged checklist binder. Fixates on 'comparability' and uses the finding to block final sign-off until an incident page, waiver, or no-anomaly test printout is attached.

possibleOutcomes.description: An EAC Finding Slip is issued: final sign-off will be blocked unless you attach an incident page, a waiver, or a no-anomaly test printout from Operations.

scenes.sceneDescription: A room full of compliance notices. Most are generic enough to be ignored, which is why you ignore them. One set uses a barcode format that feels slightly wrong—too clean, too standardized—but it’s filed as ordinary, so you treat it as ordinary.

characters.notes: POV character; methodically scans the notices, mostly ignores them; briefly registers the unfamiliar, too-clean barcode format as 'ordinary' and moves on.
Not physically present; implied authorship/jurisdictional imprint via the standardized non-local compliance notices and recurring high-contrast barcode format (Act III payoff).

possibleOutcomes.description: You notice but do not yet understand the non-local compliance language.

effects.value: Notices room: standardized templates; one barcode format unfamiliar. Filed as ordinary.

scenes.sceneDescription: In the forms rack you find a training waiver template that reads like it was written by someone trying to define ‘trained’ out of existence. It is, in other words, perfect.

characters.notes: Explores the forms rack and collects the training waiver template; dryly appreciates the liability-minimizing wording.

possibleOutcomes.description: You collect the training waiver template needed to satisfy the operations interlock in a defensible way.

scenes.sceneDescription: You fax the training waiver template to Legal. Legal returns a signed waiver with language so carefully bracketed it could survive a lawsuit and a flood. It does not say you are trained. It says the building should pretend you are, for a limited purpose, while everyone stays calm.

characters.notes: Physically in the Copy and Fax Room; faxes the training waiver template and receives the returned signed waiver.

Offsite; returns a signed training waiver with narrowly bracketed, liability-minimizing language that does not certify training—only permits the building to treat the PLAYER as trained for a limited purpose.

possibleOutcomes.description: You obtain a signed training waiver that can satisfy the training-date interlock.

scenes.sceneDescription: The operations corridor is where the facility becomes honest about what it values: interlocks, tags, and the ability to say you followed procedure. The door ahead wants a training date token, and the wall wants you to admit you will be accountable for everything you touch.

characters.notes: Navigates the corridor’s procedural barriers; reads and evaluates the training-date interlock, LOTO points/tags, and ventilation status dependency with methodical, compliance-literate attention.

possibleOutcomes.description: You identify the three main ops barriers: training-date interlock, LOTO requirements, and a ventilation status dependency.

scenes.sceneDescription: The interlock demands a training date as if the machine itself will be comforted by a timestamp. You can satisfy it with a signed waiver, or with a token-sticker hack that the system recognizes as ‘date-shaped.’ Either way, the building gets to pretend it did due diligence.

characters.notes: Interacts with the training date interlock panel; resolves the gate either by presenting a signed waiver (paperwork-compliant) or by applying a token-sticker substitution the system reads as 'date-shaped' (progress now, audit risk later).

possibleOutcomes.description: You satisfy the training gate using the signed waiver.
You satisfy the training gate with an improvised token sticker, risking later audit conflict but enabling progress.

scenes.sceneDescription: LOTO wants tags you don’t have because the facility assumes a staffed world. You apply the single real inspection tag to the main point and print temporary tags for subpoints. It’s not elegant. It is, however, documented, which is the facility’s definition of safe.

characters.notes: Interacts directly with the LOTO main lock point; applies the single real inspection tag to the main point and uses the label maker to print TEMPORARY tags for subpoints. Emphasize procedural competence and documentation-first safety framing.

possibleOutcomes.description: LOTO is satisfied using one real tag plus printed temporary tags.

scenes.sceneDescription: A ventilation status indicator refuses to say OPEN. The procedure placards argue about whose job this is, but the light doesn’t care about scope; it cares about state.

characters.notes: Interacts with the ventilation status indicator and placards; realizes ops start sequence is interlocked until the vent damper reports OPEN.

possibleOutcomes.description: You learn the ops start sequence is blocked until the ventilation damper reports OPEN.

scenes.sceneDescription: Behind the duct access panel, the damper linkage is stuck in a way that suggests it failed politely a long time ago. You free it and set it to OPEN. The action is simple, competent, and deeply offensive to a building that wants everything to be solved by forms.

characters.notes: Interacts with the ventilation access panel; frees the stuck damper linkage and sets it to OPEN with competent, no-nonsense maintenance behavior.

possibleOutcomes.description: The damper reports OPEN, clearing the unrelated subsystem dependency.

scenes.sceneDescription: The control room is a layered argument between eras of labeling. Consoles glow with mismatched terminology. A baseline log printer sits ready, like the only witness you can rely on that won’t later claim it was “out of scope.”

characters.notes: Enters the control room and assesses the consoles, alarm panel, and baseline log printer; focuses on establishing a defensible paper trail before interacting with operational controls.

possibleOutcomes.description: You gain access to operational controls and logging systems.

scenes.sceneDescription: You start baseline logging and pull the first printout. It’s time-stamped, mundane, and therefore powerful. The paper warms your hand in a way that makes you briefly feel like you’re holding jurisdiction.

characters.notes: Initiates baseline logging by interacting with the log printer tray; pulls the first time-stamped printout and treats it as a protective paper-trail artifact.

possibleOutcomes.description: Baseline logging begins; you obtain a time-stamped operational printout.

scenes.sceneDescription: You initiate the Operational Status Verification checklist. The procedure insists it is a pre-shutdown verification, which is a comforting lie. The system accepts your input and begins watching you back.

characters.notes: Initiates the Operational Status Verification checklist via the procedure binder; performs the input that starts the verification state and enables the reflectivity test requirement.

possibleOutcomes.description: Operational verification becomes active, enabling the reflectivity test requirement.

scenes.sceneDescription: From the observation deck you can finally see the machine as a whole: three independent rotating frames with mismatched maintenance markings, and a central containment sphere that is dull and over-insulated in normal operation. It looks like infrastructure pretending it isn’t.

characters.notes: Takes in the full SPINDLE assembly from the observation deck; visually verifies nominal state and identifies the reflectivity test station and return canister tray.

possibleOutcomes.description: You visually confirm SPINDLE’s nominal state and identify the reflectivity test station and return canister tray.

scenes.sceneDescription: You perform the sanctioned reflectivity test using the calibration puck. During a brief alignment flicker, the sphere surface turns mirror-smooth for a heartbeat—reflecting impossible angles—and the puck vanishes on contact. A moment later, a pneumatic tube canister clunks into the return tray with a label: “MISROUTED ITEM – RETURN TO ORIGIN NODE.”

characters.notes: Performs the sanctioned reflectivity test with the calibration puck; witnesses the brief mirror-smooth alignment flicker and the puck vanishing on contact; documents the unexpected reflective behavior and retrieves the misrouted canister return label artifact from the tube tray.

possibleOutcomes.description: Unexpected reflective behavior is documented; you obtain the misrouted item label artifact.

scenes.sceneDescription: On the chamber floor, the containment sphere dominates the room, seated in a recessed cradle. Witness marker tape defines a safe perimeter, which is also, conveniently, the zone where the system can decide you are relevant mass.

characters.notes: Alone on the chamber floor, observing the containment sphere and noticing the witness marker tape perimeter and the interface scan panel as the practical point-of-no-return zone.

possibleOutcomes.description: You identify the witness requirement zone and the interface scan panel as the physical ‘point of no return’ area.

scenes.sceneDescription: Mid-verification, the grid requests load shedding. The building alarms interpret it as both urgent and routine, which is their preferred emotional range. The shutdown verification procedure insists on stability during demand events before authorization can proceed.

characters.notes: Interacts with the alarm panel and must respond to the load-shedding demand while maintaining the verification checklist/paper trail.
Initiates the load-shedding request; insists on timestamped confirmations and documentation during the demand event.
Frames the alarms and response as routine procedure; pushes for logs/printouts and terminology discipline; helps interpret console/interlock requirements without endorsing novel explanations.

possibleOutcomes.description: A demand event is active, forcing you to reroute loads to satisfy contradictory instructions.

scenes.sceneDescription: You reroute breakers to satisfy both ‘shed load’ and ‘maintain stability’ by redefining what the building considers noncritical. The rotating frames respond by sliding toward a rare geometry. The sphere’s surface begins to glint like a mirror that doesn’t want witnesses.

characters.notes: Interacts with the Main console to reroute breakers and redefine noncritical loads; initiates the alignment sequence as a consequence of satisfying contradictory operational demands.
Load-shedding event context; applies grid-stability pressure and expects timestamped confirmation and documentation while the player changes breaker routing.
Operations-side voice (remote or intermittent) reinforcing interlock/logging discipline; avoids interpretive language about the sphere and frames the action as routine operational procedure.

possibleOutcomes.description: Alignment begins; the device approaches the latent phase-lock state.

scenes.sceneDescription: The final verification step requires a physical witness at the device. Standing near the sphere, you watch the surface phase-lock into full mirror state. Local inertial reference breaks in a way no procedure tab can explain. The system classifies you as attached mass.

characters.notes: Physically present at the containment sphere to satisfy the verification 'witness' requirement; observes the surface phase-lock into full mirror state and is subsequently classified by the system as attached mass.

possibleOutcomes.description: You are routed through the phase-locked surface into Act II.

scenes.sceneDescription: You land in a clean civic-industrial concourse built around a service bay that contains a local mirror-surface aperture. The architecture isn’t alien; it’s policy made physical. Your radio works only near the bay, fading as soon as you step away.

characters.notes: Arrives into the Overflow Intake Concourse; discovers radio range-limit near the aperture bay and begins noticing the environment’s token-driven access logic.

Present in LIM-01 as a roving intake helper. Can proactively cue the core rule that doors/kiosks respond to tokens, not people, and steer the player toward filing/survival framing without overriding policy.

possibleOutcomes.description: You understand the local rule: doors and kiosks respond to tokens, not people.

scenes.sceneDescription: You scan the misrouted-item barcode. The kiosk does not react to you as a visitor; it reacts as if you are material that failed to arrive where it was filed to arrive. It prints a slip: “UNALLOCATED MASS (ATTACHED). NEXT STEP: INTAKE (WINDOW 0).”

characters.notes: Interacts with the Barcode kiosk by scanning the misrouted-item barcode; is processed by the system as 'material that failed to arrive' and receives the printed UNALLOCATED MASS routing slip.

possibleOutcomes.description: You receive the Routing Slip: Unallocated Mass, which both opens and blocks progress depending on whether you can turn it into existence.

scenes.sceneDescription: The Intake Hall is five windows and a forms rack. Each window has a stamp tray. The building is calm in the way a DMV is calm: it isn’t hostile; it’s just certain that you are not a person until you are filed as one.

characters.notes: Navigates the five-window Intake Hall; seeks the correct window/path to obtain a Temporary Existence Receipt (TER) and establish standing.
Primary window interaction for filing the PLAYER as a fileable entity; issues TER only within acceptable categories; careful, defensive wording ('in the normal sense').
Roving support presence in the hall; provides category hints and practical routing advice without overriding policy; frames choices as 'be wrong, or be filed.'

possibleOutcomes.description: You identify Window 0 as the path to a Temporary Existence Receipt.

scenes.sceneDescription: Intake can’t file a person who isn’t listed in any jurisdiction. Intake can file an object with a barcode and an incident category. You pick a category the system will accept, then let it treat you as attached mass rather than a human with opinions.

characters.notes: Interacts at Window 0 to obtain a TER by choosing a fileable non-person category; may deliberately accept being treated as attached mass/accessory to progress.

Processes the filing only if the selected category is acceptable to the system; refuses personhood/jurisdiction arguments; careful wording ('in the normal sense'); issues TER and temporary badge once successfully categorized.

Optional nearby support who provides 'this week' category hints and directs the player toward choices that avoid rejection loops; does not perform the filing themselves or argue with the clerk on record.

possibleOutcomes.description: You register your toolbag by serial/category and file yourself as attached accessory mass.
You file as backfeed residue (persistent, nonhazardous), choosing a category the building knows how to ignore safely.
You use local process hints to pick an acceptable category ‘this week,’ then complete the filing yourself.

scenes.sceneDescription: Orientation explains the building’s rules with a calm sincerity that suggests the rules have hurt people before. On the back of the pamphlet, someone has sketched a corridor shortcut like it was contraband kindness.

characters.notes: Interacts with Window 3 to read the building rules and collect the Orientation pamphlet; notices the contraband-like corridor shortcut sketch on the back.

possibleOutcomes.description: You gain an orientation pamphlet and a practical shortcut hint.

scenes.sceneDescription: Safety issues you a glove tag. It is framed as PPE accountability, but it’s also a token that the service corridors will accept as proof you are allowed to be near other people’s mechanisms.

characters.notes: Interacts with Window 5: Safety to receive the glove tag; treat the 'Safety' issuance as an automated window process or unnamed clerk (no additional named character present).

possibleOutcomes.description: You obtain the glove tag, which functions as a service-route token.

scenes.sceneDescription: Property hands you a claim stub. The clerk’s wording is careful: the stub does not say you own anything, only that something can be assigned to an owner if you can prove it is the sort of thing that can be owned.

characters.notes: Collects the property claim stub; stays concise and procedural.

Acts as the Window 7: Property clerk for this interaction; provides the claim stub with carefully constrained wording that avoids asserting ownership, only potential assignment pending proof of ownability.

possibleOutcomes.description: You obtain the property claim stub needed for ownership logic later.

scenes.sceneDescription: Complaints stamps your slip “Processed, no action.” The stamp is meant to end conversations, which makes it a valuable currency in a system built out of endings.

characters.notes: Presents the slip for processing; keeps dialogue minimal and procedural to obtain the 'Processed, no action' complaint stamp as a usable policy substitute.
Acts as the Window 9 (Complaints) function here: stamps the slip 'Processed, no action' to terminate the interaction; avoids discussion and sticks to implication-safe wording.

possibleOutcomes.description: You obtain the complaint stamp, usable later as a policy-compliant substitute.

scenes.sceneDescription: The map kiosk prints a fragment instead of a full map, as if the building is rationing comprehension. The fragment is still useful: corridors, intake rails, and the first hint that ‘interconnection’ is treated like maintenance, not movement.

characters.notes: Interacts with the map kiosk under TER authorization; receives a rationed partial printout (Map Fragment #1) rather than a full map.

possibleOutcomes.description: You obtain Map Fragment 1: concourse and service corridors.

scenes.sceneDescription: You scan your routing barcode at the archive catalog terminal. The record that returns treats you as a recurring issue tied to an existing endpoint: “SOL-EARTH-LOCAL.” It also hints at a managing authority upstream, unnamed, as if naming it would create standing.

characters.notes: Initiates the interaction by scanning their routing barcode at the catalog terminal; internal reaction/reading focus as the legacy record frames them as a recurring issue tied to SOL-EARTH-LOCAL.

Present in LIM-04 and associated with the catalog terminal and index rules; enforces proper query framing and treats curiosity as misfiling. Will allow retrieval of legacy metadata without interpreting motives; will not name upstream authority unless forced by citation.

possibleOutcomes.description: You obtain legacy metadata that frames you as maintenance tied to an existing node, not a new anomaly.

effects.value: Archive: Endpoint SOL-EARTH-LOCAL; managing authority indicated as upstream/external (unnamed).

scenes.sceneDescription: Maintenance Triage refuses to ‘own’ a talking unknown mass, but they understand recurring endpoints. You present yourself as a corrective maintenance issue tied to SOL-EARTH-LOCAL. Once framed as a problem that already exists, they can sponsor you without admitting they’re inventing precedent.

characters.notes: Presents self as a corrective maintenance issue tied to SOL-EARTH-LOCAL; stays concise and procedural, avoids speculative framing that would imply novelty/precedent.

Refuses to 'own' a talking unknown mass; will proceed only if framed as an existing endpoint/failure mode within maintenance scope and warranty language; issues AMR entry/tag/printout and a scope-limited tool once liability is contained by wording.

possibleOutcomes.description: Triage creates an Attached Mass Registry (AMR) entry and issues a physical AMR tag and printout, plus a scope-limited tool.

scenes.sceneDescription: Scheduling is a cage with glass and a moral stance. Time slots are treated as property. The no-show recovery bin sits nearby like an accusation with handles.

characters.notes: Arrives with AMR already issued; must learn/accept that scheduling operates on asset-claim logic rather than requests.

Behind the caged window; treats time slots as property/assets. Will only respond to valid token claims (e.g., no-show recovery) and proper stamp/clearance chain; avoids empathy or framing anything as a favor.

possibleOutcomes.description: You learn that you don’t get a slot by asking; you get one by claiming an asset.

scenes.sceneDescription: You claim a no-show slot reserved for “mass that failed to arrive.” The phrasing fits you too well. The bin yields a stamped chit: a time asset with enough authority to be real until someone audits it.

characters.notes: Claims a no-show slot token from the recovery bin; internal reaction to the wording ('mass that failed to arrive') lands as dry, procedural self-recognition.

Present behind the caged window as the system’s human enforcement layer; does not assist during the self-serve no-show claim unless directly engaged, and treats the token as an asset whose validity lasts only until audit.

possibleOutcomes.description: You obtain a slot token needed to request interconnection clearance.

scenes.sceneDescription: A board lists approved stamp substitutions, which is a delightful admission that the system runs on workarounds as a formal category. ‘Processed, no action’ is listed as a valid substitute for a stamp that is functionally unobtainable.

characters.notes: Interacts with and reads the stamp substitution board; internalizes the workaround-as-policy implication.
Physically present behind the caged scheduling window as ambient institutional pressure; not required to speak unless the interaction is expanded into dialogue.

possibleOutcomes.description: You learn the complaint stamp can be used as a policy-compliant substitute in the clearance chain.

scenes.sceneDescription: You submit your paperwork for an Interconnection Work Order. You do not call it travel. You do not call it return. The clerk doesn’t correct you; they correct the form. A muttered aside: an upstream authority will reject the packet if your node isn’t in good standing.

characters.notes: Submits paperwork for an Interconnection Work Order using maintenance terminology; avoids calling it 'travel' or 'return.' Keeps responses concise and procedural.

Behind the caged window, reviews and corrects the form rather than the player's wording; treats time slots as assets and paperwork as claims. Mutters an aside that an upstream authority may reject the packet if the node isn’t in good standing; frames this as policy, not opinion.

possibleOutcomes.description: You receive an Interconnection Work Order (IWO) / Clearance packet and can proceed to staging.

scenes.sceneDescription: Staging treats you like a load that needs balancing. You clip the AMR tag into the reader loop and set up a dummy mass fixture and test load panel. The supervisor station’s labels insist this is ‘reverse routing correction,’ as if a phrase can prevent a thing from being true.

characters.notes: Performs staging setup: clips AMR tag into reader loop, configures dummy mass fixture and test load panel; internal POV framing.
Oversees staging compliance; enforces terminology ('reverse routing correction'); ensures AMR tag + slot token + IWO validity before allowing progression to the aperture bay.

possibleOutcomes.description: Staging requirements are recognized; you can proceed to the aperture bay once the test load is balanced.

scenes.sceneDescription: The mirror-surface aperture blooms into a condition that looks like your sphere’s mirror state, but packaged as infrastructure. Standing at the painted radio mark, you catch fading Earth fragments—Legal debating whether absence counts as abandonment, Budget freezing your bonus, someone asking if your tools are now foreign assets—then the signal dies. You trigger reverse routing correction and let the system pretend this is maintenance.

characters.notes: Physically present at LIM-08; stands on the radio sweet-spot floor mark, initiates reverse routing correction, and frames the event as maintenance.
Heard only as fading Earth-side radio fragments debating definitional liability (e.g., absence vs abandonment); no direct interaction before signal dies.
Heard only as fading Earth-side radio fragments applying leverage (e.g., freezing the completion bonus, reclassifying assets); no direct interaction before signal dies.

possibleOutcomes.description: You are routed back to the Earth facility, entering Act III conditions.

scenes.sceneDescription: You return to the chamber and the sphere is still flickering into mirror state, as if something upstream is holding the condition open. Local panels disagree on what to call it: reflective behavior, instability, test anomaly. The only name that matters is the one that ends up in your file.

characters.notes: Returns to the SPINDLE chamber and observes the containment sphere flickering into mirror-state; must reassert institutional presence via documentation and start an aggressive paper trail.
Available as an operations voice tied to HUB-13 consoles/logging; will frame the instability in maintenance/procedure language and resist interpretive terms.
Implied upstream hold keeping the mirror-state condition open; may manifest via notices/reference numbers and standing/service-class language tied to HUB-13.

possibleOutcomes.description: Act III begins; you must reassert presence and start an aggressive paper trail.

scenes.sceneDescription: Back in the control room, logging stops being good practice and becomes self-defense. You can’t let the building decide you are ‘missing’ again, because ‘missing’ becomes ‘incident’ when the wrong person summarizes it.

characters.notes: Prioritizes producing time-stamped baseline logs/printouts as defensible proof of presence; treats logging as self-defense and avoids speculative phrasing that could be weaponized in later summaries.

possibleOutcomes.description: You prioritize time-stamped proof of presence and stabilize the room’s operational posture.

scenes.sceneDescription: You pull a fresh log printout to prove you are physically present on-site after return. It’s boring on purpose. The boredom is the point: boredom is what auditors believe.

characters.notes: Physically pulls the fresh, time-stamped log printout from the baseline printer tray as presence proof; plays it straight and procedural—boredom is the credibility.

possibleOutcomes.description: You obtain time-stamped presence proof to anchor the Act III timeline.

scenes.sceneDescription: The tube station clunks like it never stopped being used—just not by anyone you know. A dot-matrix printout appears with barcodes and a reference number: “NOTICE: Unauthorized load detected. Origin Node: SOL-EARTH-LOCAL. Managing Authority: METASTABLE TRANSFER AUTHORITY (MTA). Action: Hold state pending compliance.” It looks like a contractor letter until you read the parts that don’t fit any contractor.

characters.notes: Examines/collects the dot-matrix printout from the pneumatic tube station; recognizes it as bureaucratic but anomalous enough to trigger evidence-building.
Appears only through the MTA-branded NOTICE printout with barcodes/reference number; enforcement tone is procedural (standing/hold/compliance), not overtly hostile.

possibleOutcomes.description: You obtain the MTA Notice and a reference number, establishing upstream standing as an actionable fact.

scenes.sceneDescription: The notices room stops being generic. The unfamiliar barcode format matches the MTA notice. The language matches the phrasing you heard in Act II: overflow, backfeed, routing correction. The room has been telling you the truth since Act I; you just didn’t have the context to recognize it as truth.

characters.notes: Interacts with the out-of-place notice; makes the Act III recognition that the room’s 'generic' compliance postings have been MTA-origin all along. No dialogue required; discovery is internal/procedural.

Not physically present; represented through the standardized barcode format and MTA phrasing embedded in the notices (overflow/backfeed/routing correction). The scene reframes these artifacts as upstream enforcement paperwork.

possibleOutcomes.description: You recognize the non-local compliance notices as MTA-origin forms and gain access to variance language.

scenes.sceneDescription: Using the scan panel as if the sphere were an addressable surface, you submit a Temporary Operating Variance packet that the building can route. The act is mostly paperwork, but the machine behaves as if it understands the difference between ‘variance’ and ‘panic.’

characters.notes: Interacts with the Interface scan panel to submit the Temporary Operating Variance packet; treats the act as procedural paperwork to buy time.

Presence is indirect (notice/acknowledgment routed through the building). Issues the variance acknowledgment as queue/processing time, framed in standing/service-class terms rather than narrative explanation.

possibleOutcomes.description: A variance acknowledgment arrives, buying a short hold period framed as ‘processing time.’

scenes.sceneDescription: Records is locked again, but now you have the kinds of numbers that doors respect: a time-stamped presence printout and an MTA notice reference. The seal strip is replaced, the door opens, and Records yields what it always had: billing ledgers, maintenance schedules from elsewhere, and audit flags that predate the incident everyone keeps calling 1987.

characters.notes: Uses the time-stamped presence printout and MTA notice reference to bypass the renewed seal and enter Records; retrieves the billing ledgers, non-local maintenance schedules, and pre-incident audit flags as evidence.

May be unseen/implicit; Records access is treated as a chain-of-custody function that responds to correct reference handles. If encountered, remains literal and filing-focused; provides documents without interpretation or speculation.

possibleOutcomes.description: You retrieve evidence pieces that prove standing: charges, schedules, and pre-incident audit flags.

scenes.sceneDescription: You assemble an Evidence Packet binder section with a cover sheet that makes ‘MTA is real’ the least controversial statement in the room. Identifiers match across artifacts. Charges recur. Dates predate the incident narrative. The packet is structured so nobody has to feel brave to agree with it.

characters.notes: Compiles and organizes the Evidence Packet binder section at the copier: cross-checks identifiers, dates, and recurring charges; formats the packet to be maximally defensible and low-risk for others to agree with.

possibleOutcomes.description: The Evidence Packet section is compiled and ready to be used to secure a valid closure path.

scenes.sceneDescription: You draft an Authorized Closure Path memo that references the MTA notice numbers and your Evidence Packet. It isn’t a meeting. It’s a collision of fixations: definitions, budgets, stability, warranty, and your need to exist long enough to finish the checklist.

characters.notes: Physically in HUB-09, drafting the Authorized Closure Path memo; pulls MTA notice numbers and cites the compiled Evidence Packet to build a defensible paper trail and secure an executable endgame with minimal narrative risk.

Not physically present; their fixation on definition control shapes the memo’s phrasing (tight scope, no admissions of novelty, careful verbs). Any implied authorization is avoided; language reads like narrow-purpose compliance.

Not physically present; their fiscal cutoff leverage and cost framing pressures the memo toward a 'boring' closure narrative, emphasizing audit survivability, deliverable completion, and minimizing research-triggering implications.
Not physically present; their warranty/scope obsession pushes the memo to classify actions as covered work and to avoid statements that assign open-ended facility responsibility.

Not physically present; their grid-stability mindset echoes in the memo as timestamped accountability language, stability assurances, and documentation-first framing of any load or operational state references.

Not physically present; appears via referenced MTA notice numbers and standing/service-class bureaucracy. The memo is written to satisfy their procedural brittleness (queue/standing logic) without inviting broader jurisdictional escalation.

possibleOutcomes.description: You produce a closure path memo and choose an endgame approach to execute with a clean paper trail.

scenes.sceneDescription: Endgame path selected: terminal shutdown. You treat collapse as safety containment, not rebellion. The upstream hold resists, forcing you to interrupt the alignment lock while keeping logs running and tags placed where Legal can defend them.

characters.notes: Initiates terminal shutdown as safety containment (not rebellion). Must keep actions defensible: maintain chain-of-custody tags, avoid speculative language, and remain physically present as required by witness/zone constraints.
Insists on interlocks, printouts, and timestamped logs staying active during shutdown. Polices terminology (never 'travel'); frames actions as procedure and timeline protection.

Represents the upstream compliance hold resisting collapse. Communicates via notices/holds/queue language; applies standing/service-class logic. Not malicious, but procedurally brittle and obstructive.

Provides definition-safe framing and waiver/work-order language to support the 'safety containment' narrative. Corrects implicature (avoid 'still', avoid novelty admissions); advises on tag wording so Legal can defend the file later.

possibleOutcomes.description: Routes collapse; the node is forced toward shutdown with a defensible safety narrative.

scenes.sceneDescription: Endgame path selected: renegotiate Earth’s classification. You frame SOL-EARTH-LOCAL as legacy municipal infrastructure, assemble the least-offensive service class language you can find, and build a signature chain that treats ‘acknowledge’ and ‘accept’ as functional authority.

characters.notes: Executes the renegotiation tactic at the main console: reframes SOL-EARTH-LOCAL as legacy municipal infrastructure; assembles service-class language; constructs a signature/authority chain where 'acknowledge' and 'accept' function as operational authority.
Provides definition-control and waiver-style phrasing; insists on narrow-purpose language that avoids admitting novelty/precedent while still producing a defensible signature chain.

Represents upstream standing/service-class enforcement; responds to the reclassification request in bureaucratic terms (standing indicators, queue position, licensed relationship). Not malicious; procedurally brittle.
Pushes for an outcome that closes exposure and keeps the interconnection operational without triggering research/investigation categories; frames choices in cost/liability terms.

Maintains console/log discipline during the renegotiation steps; emphasizes procedure, printouts, and acceptable terminology (never 'travel'); ensures actions are logged as routine operational maintenance.

possibleOutcomes.description: Earth’s node status is reclassified into a licensed relationship; the interconnection remains operational under a new category.

scenes.sceneDescription: Endgame path selected: hide alignment inside acceptable tolerances. You calibrate sensors and thresholds so mirror-state entry reads as a measurement artifact. The machine becomes ‘boringly stable’ on paper, which is often indistinguishable from ‘safe’ in institutional practice.

characters.notes: Calibrates control-room sensors/thresholds to keep mirror-state alignment readings within 'acceptable tolerances' and ensure logs frame any anomaly as measurement artifact; maintains a defensible paper trail (printer/logs/checklist).

possibleOutcomes.description: The portal function is suppressed under nominal operation and can only be invoked deliberately under controlled conditions.

scenes.sceneDescription: Endgame path selected: redirect liability. You use contract archaeology and scope language to pin responsibility on an entity that can absorb it—because the system always needs a box to put the cause in, and you are tired of being the most convenient box.

characters.notes: Executes the liability-redirect endgame: pulls old contract language, assembles a defensible memo, and routes it via Records/tube as needed. Stays concise; lets documentation do the work.
Controls access to ledgers and contract artifacts; enforces chain-of-custody and correct identifiers. Refuses interpretation; will file/stamp/release only what is properly referenced.

Provides tightly-scoped, definition-controlled language that redirects responsibility without admitting novelty or intent. Will not 'authorize' actions; will issue wording that makes the paper trail defensible.
Frames the decision as exposure management and audit survivability; pushes for a clean reassignment of liability that protects OLEA and keeps the closure deliverable intact.

Participates through notices, reference numbers, and service-class/standing language that can be used as the 'official box' to assign responsibility upstream. Procedurally brittle; avoids narrative explanations.

Referenced/played as legacy scope-disclaimer evidence; not physically present. Provides reusable exclusion language that can be weaponized to justify redirecting responsibility to a contractor/entity built to absorb it.

possibleOutcomes.description: Your personal exposure is reduced; responsibility is reassigned via a defensible paper trail.
